defs.docs:
This crate is designed to make it easy to build interactive computer art
 with just a pixel buffer. For inspiration, consider looking at
 <https://shadertoy.com> and <http://www.iquilezles.org/www/index.htm>,
 there are a lot of cool art pieces to see and explanations of fun techniques!

attributes.value: deny(missing_docs)
! This crate is designed to make it easy to build interactive computer art
! with just a pixel buffer. For inspiration, consider looking at
! <https://shadertoy.com> and <http://www.iquilezles.org/www/index.htm>,
! there are a lot of cool art pieces to see and explanations of fun techniques!
! # Usage
! To make a piece of art, you create and configure a [`Canvas`] object, and
! then you ask it to [`render`] with your code. The canvas will do state
! management and hand you an image to modify. Whatever modifications you make
! to the image will be displayed on the screen.
! [`Canvas`]: struct.Canvas.html
! [`render`]: struct.Canvas.html#method.render
! # Example
! ```rust,no_run
! use pixel_canvas::{Canvas, Color, input::MouseState};
! fn main() {
!     // Configure the window that you want to draw in. You can add an event
!     // handler to build interactive art. Input handlers for common use are
!     // provided.
!     let canvas = Canvas::new(512, 512)
!         .title("Tile")
!         .state(MouseState::new())
!         .input(MouseState::handle_input);
!     // The canvas will render for you at up to 60fps.
!     canvas.render(|mouse, image| {
!         // Modify the `image` based on your state.
!         let width = image.width() as usize;
!         for (y, row) in image.chunks_mut(width).enumerate() {
!             for (x, pixel) in row.iter_mut().enumerate() {
!                 let dx = x as i32 - mouse.x;
!                 let dy = y as i32 - mouse.y;
!                 let dist = dx * dx + dy * dy;
!                 *pixel = Color {
!                     r: if dist < 128 * 128 { dy as u8 } else { 0 },
!                     g: if dist < 128 * 128 { dx as u8 } else { 0 },
!                     b: (x * y) as u8,

defs.name: canvas
defs.docs:
The [`Canvas`] is the main entry point of the library. It handles window
 creation and input, calls your render callback, and presents the image on
 the screen.

attributes.value: ! The [`Canvas`] is the main entry point of the library. It handles window
! creation and input, calls your render callback, and presents the image on
! the screen.
! You create and configure a [`Canvas`] via builder methods. You can create
! a perfectly functionl, bare-bones canvas just by calling [`Canvas::new`]
! with your dimensions, and then calling [`render`]. If you
! want a fancier canvas (like handling input, with a custom title, etc.) you
! can configure that as well. For example:
! ```rust
! # use pixel_canvas::{Canvas, input::MouseState};
! let canvas = Canvas::new(512, 512)
!     .title("Tile")
!     .hidpi(true)
!     .show_ms(true)
!     .state(MouseState::new())
!     .input(MouseState::handle_input);
! This adds a 512x512 window called "Title", that renders in hidpi mode,
! displays the frame rendering time, and tracks the position of the mouse in
! physical pixels. For more information on event handlers, see the [`input`]
! module.
! [`Canvas`]: struct.Canvas.html
! [`Canvas::new`]: struct.Canvas.html#method.new
! [`render`]: struct.Canvas.html#method.render
! [`input`]: ../input/index.html
! Once you've created your canvas, you can use it to render your art. Do
! whatever you want in the render callback, the image you build will be
! displayed in the window when your render callback returns.
! ```rust,no_run
! # use pixel_canvas::{Canvas, Color, input::MouseState};
! # fn make_your_own_color(x: usize, y: usize, mx: i32, my: i32) -> Color {
! #     Color { r: 0, g: 0, b: 0 }
! # let canvas = Canvas::new(512, 512).state(MouseState::new());
! canvas.render(|mouse, image| {
!     let width = image.width() as usize;
!     for (y, row) in image.chunks_mut(width).enumerate() {
!         for (x, pixel) in row.iter_mut().enumerate() {
!             *pixel = make_your_own_color(x, y, mouse.x, mouse.y);

defs.name: EventHandler
defs.docs: A type that represents an event handler.

attributes.value: / A type that represents an event handler.
/ It returns true if the state is changed.

defs.name: CanvasInfo
defs.value: CanvasInfo { width, height, title, hidpi, dpi, show_ms, render_on_change }
defs.docs: Information about the [`Canvas`](struct.Canvas.html).

attributes.value: / Information about the [`Canvas`](struct.Canvas.html).

defs.name: width
defs.docs: The width of the canvas, in virtual pixels.

attributes.value: / The width of the canvas, in virtual pixels.

defs.name: height
defs.docs: The height of the canvas, in virtual pixels.

attributes.value: / The height of the canvas, in virtual pixels.

defs.name: title
defs.docs: The base title for the window.

attributes.value: / The base title for the window.

defs.name: hidpi
defs.docs: Whether the canvas will render in hidpi mode. Defaults to `false`.

attributes.value: / Whether the canvas will render in hidpi mode. Defaults to `false`.

defs.name: dpi
defs.docs:
The DPI factor. If hidpi is on, the virtual dimensions are multiplied
 by this factor to create the actual image resolution. For example, if
 you're on a Retina Macbook, this will be 2.0, so the image will be
 twice the resolution that you specified.

attributes.value: / The DPI factor. If hidpi is on, the virtual dimensions are multiplied
/ by this factor to create the actual image resolution. For example, if
/ you're on a Retina Macbook, this will be 2.0, so the image will be
/ twice the resolution that you specified.

defs.name: show_ms
defs.docs:
Whether the window title will display the time to render a frame.
 Defaults to `false`.

attributes.value: / Whether the window title will display the time to render a frame.
/ Defaults to `false`.

defs.name: render_on_change
defs.docs:
Only call the render callback if there's a state change.
 Defaults to `false`, which means it will instead render at a fixed framerate.

attributes.value: / Only call the render callback if there's a state change.
/ Defaults to `false`, which means it will instead render at a fixed framerate.

defs.name: Canvas
defs.docs:
A [`Canvas`](struct.Canvas.html) manages a window and event loop, handing
 the current state to the renderer, and presenting its image on the screen.

attributes.value: / A [`Canvas`](struct.Canvas.html) manages a window and event loop, handing
/ the current state to the renderer, and presenting its image on the screen.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Create a new canvas with a given virtual window dimensions.

attributes.value: / Create a new canvas with a given virtual window dimensions.

defs.name: state
defs.docs: Set the attached state.

attributes.value: / Set the attached state.
/ Attaching a new state object will reset the input handler.

defs.name: title
defs.docs: Set the title on the canvas window.

attributes.value: / Set the title on the canvas window.

defs.name: hidpi
defs.docs: Toggle hidpi render.

attributes.value: / Toggle hidpi render.
/ Defaults to `false`.
/ If you have a hidpi monitor, this will cause the image to be larger
/ than the dimensions you specified when creating the canvas.

defs.name: show_ms
defs.docs: Whether to show a frame duration in the title bar.

attributes.value: / Whether to show a frame duration in the title bar.
/ Defaults to `false`.

defs.name: render_on_change
defs.docs: Whether to render a new frame only on state changes.

attributes.value: / Whether to render a new frame only on state changes.
/ Defaults to `false`, which means it will render at a fixed framerate.

defs.name: input
defs.docs: Attach an input handler.

attributes.value: / Attach an input handler.
/ Your input handler must be compatible with any state that you've set
/ previously. Your event handler will be called for each event with the
/ canvas information, the current state, and the inciting event.

defs.name: render
defs.value: fn (mut self, mut callback: impl FnMut(&mut State, &mut Image) + 'static) -> ()
defs.docs: Provide a rendering callback.

attributes.value: / Provide a rendering callback.
/ The canvas will call your rendering callback on demant, with the
/ current state and a reference to the image. Depending on settings,
/ this will either be called at 60fps, or only called when state changes.
/ See [`render_on_change`](struct.Canvas.html#method.render_on_change).

defs.name: image
defs.docs: The [`Image`] is what you manipulate to produce your art.

attributes.value: ! The [`Image`] is what you manipulate to produce your art.
! Every frame you are given a mutable reference to the existing frame, and
! are able to modify it to produce your image.
! [`Image`]: struct.Image.html

defs.name: Image
defs.docs: An image for editing.

attributes.value: / An image for editing.
/ It dereferences to a slice of [`Color`], so you can directly manipulate
/ pixels via regular (mutable) slice methods. In addition, you can index
/ into the image by `(row, column)` pairs.
/ [`Color`]: ../color/struct.Color.html

defs.name: RC
defs.docs:
A row/column pair for indexing into an image.
 Distinct from an x/y pair.

attributes.value: / A row/column pair for indexing into an image.
/ Distinct from an x/y pair.

defs.name: XY
defs.docs:
An x/y pair for indexing into an image.
 Distinct from a row/column pair.

attributes.value: / An x/y pair for indexing into an image.
/ Distinct from a row/column pair.

defs.docs: Pre-built canvas input event handlers.

defs.name: MouseState
defs.docs: An input handler that tracks the position of the mouse.

attributes.value: / An input handler that tracks the position of the mouse.
/ It provides physical and virtual coordinates.
/ - Virtual coordinates (`virtual_x` and `virtual_y`) are as reported by the
/   OS, which means that they originate from the upper left corner and
/   account for DPI. You don't want this very often, but if you want to match
/   the OS coordinates for some reason, this is it.
/ - Physical coordinates (`x` and `y`) match the pixels in the image. This is
/   usually what you want.

defs.name: x
defs.docs:
The x position from the lower-left corner, measured in physical pixels.
 This should always correspond to the column of the pixel in the image.

attributes.value: / The x position from the lower-left corner, measured in physical pixels.
/ This should always correspond to the column of the pixel in the image.

defs.name: y
defs.docs:
The y position from the lower-left corner, measured in physical pixels.
 This should always correspond to the row of the pixel in the image.

attributes.value: / The y position from the lower-left corner, measured in physical pixels.
/ This should always correspond to the row of the pixel in the image.

defs.name: virtual_x
defs.docs:
The x position from the upper-left corner as reported by the OS,
 measured in virtual pixels.

attributes.value: / The x position from the upper-left corner as reported by the OS,
/ measured in virtual pixels.

defs.name: virtual_y
defs.docs:
The y position from the upper-left corner as reported by the OS,
 measured in virtual pixels.

attributes.value: / The y position from the upper-left corner as reported by the OS,
/ measured in virtual pixels.

defs.name: Restrict
defs.docs: Represent types that can be restricted by a given range type.

attributes.value: / Represent types that can be restricted by a given range type.
/ This would've been called `Clamp`, except that there's a standard library
/ method called `clamp`.

defs.name: restrict
defs.docs: Restrict a value into a given range.

attributes.value: / Restrict a value into a given range.
/ If a value is below the minimum bound, it should be clamped to that
/ value, and if it's above its max value it should be clamped to that.
/ This is only provided for inclusive ranges, since the behavior for
/ exclusive ranges of some types are less immediately clear.

defs.name: Remap
defs.docs: Represents a type that can be mapped between two ranges.

attributes.value: / Represents a type that can be mapped between two ranges.

attributes.value: / Remap a value from one range to another. A value outside the bounds of
/ one range will be similarly outside the bounds of the other.
